comment: Very smooth, nice light smoke. Very good to drink
Slight complexity. Excellent for home blending. Strong taste
It's got its own taste, recognizable right as you taste it, and not too expensive. Favorite everyday whisky

11/16.  Similar to JW Black but - longer better finish. More citrusy.  Less malty (more grain), thinner.  JW Black is fuller in the mouth, more malt, but very short finish.  I like this better than JWB and it's cheaper

A local liquor store owner was nice enough to share a sample with me that was left over from a recent Buchanan's tasting.  The initial delivery on this scotch is not too bad, with some sweet fruits, but the palate becomes hopelessly blurred with muddled smoke and cloying, grainy sweetness dominating the finish.  It's light bodied and inexpensive, but there are much better blended scotch values out there (the NAS Grants, for instance, blows this out of the water).  Diageo owns this blend and they do a much better job with a 12 yr old blended scotch with their iconic Johnnie Walker Black.  Not recommended, although I thought the Buchanan's 18 that I also sampled wasn't bad.

Feb 2017.  This was recommended to me as a good choice for a new-to-scotch person as well as being a flavorful blended scotch on a budget.  Saw a review that said the longer it stays in your mouth, the more it tastes like caramelized onions and that it is well paired with charred meat or poultry.  That was intriguing so I gave it a try.

Bottom line up front, this one is not for me.  I picked up what I interpreted to be overpowering pipe tobacco on the nose.  I’m not particularly fond of that so perhaps mentally I was already done with this.  The mouth feel was uneventful.  I did pick up the sweetness.  The finish had a little bite.  Never really got the caramelized onions but in its defense I was drinking this neat and without any charred meat.

I labeled this one, “Drink this when ‘regular’ friends visit or when making cocktails.”
My first "good" whisky, so I'm not able to analyse it as it should be.

Nose: Dark fruit, light smoke, salted caramel, with a hint briney of sea water. 

Taste: More jucie fruits, chocolate, a bit of brine, with a spiced walnut after taste. 

Experience: Looking into a tide pool in the summer. Summers sweetness mixed with salty discovery.

Nostalgia is a funny thing. Nearly ten years ago, I was living in Montevideo, Uruguay for a year of volunteer work between undergrad and seminary. My supervisor at the social project had the foreign volunteers over on Christmas Day; being a good uruguayo, he got the grill up and going for an asado extravaganza, and pulled out the Buchanan's. His father in law kept asking me if I wanted "más hielo" in my whisky...let's just say he that wasn't only adding ice, and I had a REALLY good Christmas. In South America, this IS scotch. It's the biggest seller. Truthfully, it's not hard to see why - it's balanced, sweet, fruity, easy to drink, and has just enough of a whisp of smoke and salinity to stay interesting. Is it a great whisky? No. It is, however, a pleasant warm
weather blend on the rocks...which makes it a great Southern Hemisphere Christmas dram. Feliz Navidad!
I’m seeing some batch variations with this one.
Thin.  Unappealing, damp smokiness upfront and not much more than tannin and pepper to finish.  There's a light sourness, I'd blame whatever grain spirit is there, that I do not like.

Nose is phenolic, floral, oak, light peat and lemon zest. Arrival is thin, tart, a hint of barley sugar and barrel tannin. Finish is dry, mostly tannins, pepper and a light spice. DeLuxe... not so much.
Peat/smoke seem to dominate, and I like others’ notes on the salinity, but there’s not a lot going on here.  Feels like the “professional reviewer” was tasting some other spirit...😜
Easy drinking with dark fruit sweetness, light oak, tobacco smoke, soft floral spice, and a slightly salty bittersweet finish. Not available in Ontario.

Peat, tobacco & light sweetness or fruit. Water brings some smoke.
      6 days later, 3rd dram or so since opening the bottle. Today the smoke is light and only in the finish. Its sweet fruit, spice and toffee in the nose. Sweet and rich tasting.
went with a taster 50ml bottle. good thing too. this is not worth buying when there are plenty of American whiskeys that are far better

Buchanan's De Luxe 12-Year has a deep golden, clear appearance, with noticeable & noble alcohol legs. The aroma is mild, yet pungent, with wax, peat smoke, a citrus peel. There is, perhaps, also an almond oil aspect. The flavor is of smoky, waxy, peat; orange pith, mild chocolate, barley bread, and a spicy finish. Mouthfeel is medium, and Buchanan's De Luxe 12-Year finishes with a slow, but not sloppy, fade. RJT
This stuff is barely drinkable to me.  While most of my friends do not agree, it tastes like alcoholic prune juice.  Has an odd, musty taste.  And the slow pour top is infuriating.
Nice fruity beginning. Progresses to spicy notes met with a smoky finish. Well balanced and perhaps a bit underrated

Orchard fruit, light peat smoke, vanilla, oak and baking spice on the nose. Vanilla right up front. Peach, meaty smoke, and spice. A nice budget blended scotch. Has fruit, wood, smoke and spice. What's not to like.
I like the taste, not so much strong is the exact amount of flavor you need
Nice blend of grain and sweetness, a little saccharin but super approachable and pleasant.

One of my favorite blends with a age statement and for price..vanilla, caramel, toffee, chocolate, floral, citrus, apple, raisin, musty, malty, grainy, smokey, good peat..pretty smooth..slight burn but not much..def island and islay whiskies in this blend..get it every once in awhile.

balanced flavor with sweet and just enough smoke to taste but not to offend the new scotch palate.  sometimes i think i pick up sweet green pepper. very pleasant scotch that i would recommend for a new scotch drinker

Appearance: This beautiful blend is khaki gold in color with exceedingly thin and viscous legs.

Nose: The nose at first appears mostly as grain “sparkle,” but with some time to open up notes of salty peat smoke, pine trees, candy honey, flowers, sour green apple and grape, and lemon zest all make appearances in the exciting nose.

Taste: The delicious palate consists of notes of sea salt, peat, orange citrus, fruity candy, honey, dark chocolate,  and campfire smoke.

Finish: There is a short to medium finish that rises up in your throat, then dives but leaves behind an almost BBQ aftertaste in the back.

Thoughts: There's a lot going on, but it's a good balanced blend. I don't mind it one bit but like it more after letting it breathe a while. I would recommend it. Buchanan’s, I can see why you are one of the top selling blended scotches out there. Keep it up! Sláinte!
Delicious, super smooth on the rocks.
Not super complex, but light and citrusy. good for a summer drink
Not bad for a blended scotch. Sweet, malty with a bit of orange peel with a little pith left on.

Fuerte aroma a madera.
Un poquito ahumado pero muy agradable al paladar

Cost-effective if you ask me, pricing at just over $30 in Southern California, a blended Scotch, drinks like a single malt, seems confused. I really only ever buy it as a gift for an old friend I enjoy drinking with on occasion late into the night, so this is perfect for that.

We did try it as shots once, and though it is doable, I highly do not recommend it, it is dumb and the burn can choke you worse than Tequila for a new drinker.

Strong smoke presence and pretty juicy, with a bit of pepper on the palate, enjoy as a finger or two.
Bit too harsh for my taste
Very light taste. Will get lost in a cocktail, best as an easy drinking neat scotch.
Sweet citrus mixed with camp fire on the nose, creamy oranges and toffee on the palate, smooth medium finish
this is good. Some sweetness and smoke. i was not mad trying this.
As an introduction to scotch it's not bad. I'm just really not a fan of peat smoke.
If you don't want to spend much money and need a regular scotch whiskey, Buchanan would b good to start with.

Citruses, tangerine lemon in the nose. Along with dark chocolate, light vanilla and creamy caramel. 

Palate: black pepper, vanilla, smoky peat, and a little bit of toffee
Aroma has hints of smoke, pear, and bacon. Flavor is like a dry cider with hints of palate cleansing smoke. Peat is there, but subtle, not unlike Highland Park.
Smokey, oakly creamy gentle scotch. Very soft and mellow.

Neat: A huge fusel burn right off the bat. Plenty of caramel, toffee and corn, but they play second fiddle to the alcohol heat. No peat or smoke whatsoever. 

With a droplet: the burn slightly decreases but not by much. The toffee and caramel dilute a bit, but prickly citrus spices come out with a floral quality.

(RECOMMENDED) With a big cube: the vanilla, caramel and toffee bloom. Dried orange peel also pops here. Ashy smoke puffs out with ice as well. It definitely benefits from dilution or a mixer.
Smooth, moderate mouth feel. Slightly sweet, not much flavor.
Drank neat.  Smoke hits your pallet hard immediately on fist sip, harshness reduces sip after sip.
Caramel on the nose and a little floral. Very sweet, mellowy and with good body, there is orange in there as well. Finnish is very short and sweet.

Pleasant and affordable but without surprises.

Color - light amber
Nose - fruit forward (pear, orange), light peat, hint of caramel hiding
Palate - buttery with smoke, some earthy tones
Finish - faint smoke, lingering of chocolate, a little oily leather on the tail end.

Personally I found water brought more of the Islay character (peat, moss, earth) and neat showcased more of a speyside (fruit, chocolate)
Below average taste. Although it's smooth, the smokey finish is unpleasant. Mellowed out a lot with a mixer.
Very smooth, well rounded for the price.
